sub_topic: Finding the period and amplitude of trigonometric functions
message_1: A ferris wheel has a diameter of 50 feet and completes one full revolution every 40 seconds. If the wheel starts at the lowest point, find the equation for the height of a rider on the ferris wheel as a function of time and determine the amplitude and period of the function.
message_2:
To find the equation for the height of a rider on the ferris wheel as a function of time, we can model the motion using a sinusoidal function. Since the wheel starts at the lowest point, we will use a cosine function.

The general form of a cosine function is:

h(t) = A * cos(B(t - C)) + D

where h(t) is the height of the rider at time t, A is the amplitude, B is the frequency, C is the phase shift, and D is the vertical shift.

The diameter of the ferris wheel is 50 feet, so the radius is 25 feet. This means that the amplitude (A) is 25 feet, as the rider moves 25 feet above and below the center of the wheel.

The period of the function is the time it takes for the wheel to complete one full revolution, which is 40 seconds. To find the frequency (B), we use the formula:

B = 2π / period

B = 2π / 40 = π / 20

Since the wheel starts at the lowest point, there is no phase shift (C = 0).

The vertical shift (D) is the height of the center of the wheel, which is equal to the radius (25 feet).

Now we can write the equation for the height of the rider as a function of time:

h(t) = 25 * cos(π/20 * t) + 25

The amplitude of the function is 25 feet, and the period is 40 seconds.
